Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Evolutionary Trends Within the Polemoniaceae (Ericales)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Polemoniaceae, the phlox family, is a textbook example of an adaptive radiation and has long been studied by biologists from diverse fields under the assumption that pollinators have played a key role in the formation of its species. However, this, hypothesis remains untested. This research explores evolution in the phlox family, a group of plants with most species found in the United States to test this this hypotheses from ecological and genetic perspectives. This research will benefit science and society by developing identification keys which will allow the public, especially members of native plant organizations, to identify and therefore have a deeper appreciation for the biological diversity of phlox. These data will also allow conservationists to make informed, cost-effective decisions as they seek to preserve endangered and threatened species at both the State and Federal level, especially in California, Nevada, Minnesota, and Wisconsin.

Polemonium has been the subject of multiple molecular phylogenetic studies yet the relationships among its species remain undetermined. Species boundaries between species are also unclear, perhaps as a result of reticulate evolution. This project will generate a near species-level phylogeny of the Polemoniaceae and will also use morphometric techniques to generate trait data. This study will be the first to sample all species and utilize multiple nuclear loci to determine species relationships. These data will test the hypothesis that floral form has been selected for by pollinators and the morphometric data will determine the evolution of leaf form. Collection data from natural history museums will be used to investigate the biogeographic history of Polemonium. The use of comparative phylogenetic methods with these data sets provides a unique opportunity to reconstruct the ancestral character states at various time periods during phlox evolution. Polemonium occidentale ssp. lacustre is endangered in both states in which it occurs, but is not yet Federally listed as endangered. Next-generation sequencing approaches will be used to determine its taxonomic status and population structure to inform conservation of this rare taxon.

POR.DRECONTENT:
New methods of sequencing and analyzing DNA sequences, as well as new methods in examining morphological evolution have opened up exciting areas for studying the evolution of groups of plant species (the field of plant systematics). This research proposal sought to expand the use of these methods and provide a guide for “best practices” to using them for other researches. As a study system, we used the plant genus Polemonium (Jacob’s Ladder, Sky Pilot) in western North America. We examined evolutionary processes within the genus, as well as within the larger context of the taxonomic order and family to which it belongs.

The first objective of this study was to examine the evolutionary history of the order Ericales and see if there were any rapid increases in the rate of species formation and in what groups they might be located. We found 70 increases in speciation rate within the order, one of which involved the ancestor of all living species of Polemonium.

Our next objective was to place the evolution of floral morphology in Polemonium in the context of the larger phlox family (Polemoniaceae). As differences in floral morphology are though to be closely linked with differences in pollinator type (floral syndromes), we also tested the association of these floral traits with what animal(s) they are pollinated by. We scored 11 quantitative and 2 qualitative floral traits for over 370 members of the family. In conjunction with a phylogenetic tree, we found that movement to different kinds of pollinator is associated with changes in floral morphology, but there is a lag between shifts. Shifts in pollinators tend to occur before rapid changes in morphological traits.

Our third objective was to study the evolutionary relationships in Polemonium. For many reasons, genealogy of a given gene in the genome may not match the history of the species. One such reason is the process of reticulate evolution, in which unrelated groups exchange genetic material. New computational methods allow us to test for the presence of this phenomenon, however few studies have actually done so. We used 360 genes to examine this question. We found many different genealogical histories in this sample and found evidence that at least three reticulate evolution events have occurred in the history of Polemonium. We also found that the history of the chloroplast genome is incompatible with the history of the nuclear genome.  This may be due to low-level interbreeding between different species in the last few tens of thousand of years.

Lastly, we examined processes acting at the population level. We used western Jacob’s ladder (Polemonium occidentale ssp. lacustre) as our study system. This organism is restricted to Minnesota and Wisconsin and is endangered in both states, but little is known about its biology. We sequenced 69,000 variable DNA sites from throughout its genome from 94 individuals from all known populations. We found that although all populations were very genetically similar and individuals within populations were not very genetically diverse, most populations are not interbreeding much. We found the Wisconsin and two southern Minnesota populations to be genetically isolated, while two northern Minnesota populations have exchanged genetic information in the recent past.

In terms of broader impacts, this study helps place studies investigating how natural selection acts on evolution of floral traits within populations of a given species into a broader evolutionary context. It questions how strong natural section is acting on floral traits on the scale of tens of millions of years. The evolution of floral form over longer evolutionary timescales may instead involve a tradeoff of pollination efficiency and ability to maintain vegetative organs. In addition, our methodology provides a workflow for other systematists interested in the evolution of morphological traits to examine correlations between morphological and ecological variables while taking into account evolutionary relationships. It also helps guide future systematists in the “best practices” for getting the most out of their datasets as they sequence hundreds or thousands of genes and to best account for all evolutionary processes in their dataset. Lastly, the results of our population genetic study provide guidance to natural resource managers in the Upper Midwest as they decide how best to conserve rare species.
